content: Due to community feedback, updated difficulty to medium :)
Removed the trailing \n which appears in the output of some test cases and some validators.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very interesting puzzle. However this puzzle is  practically medium level for me.

Hello Smelty,
In the test case number 10 composed by 9, 12, 12, 13.
The output should return true instead of false.

I am done with testing. I am convinced that it is not an easy puzzle but rather medium.

I tested 24 possible permutations (factorial 4),
4 possible operations give 4^3 = 64 results,
If you consider associations using parenthesis you have to multiply everything by 3.

Total : 24 * 64 * 3 = 4608 results from 4 numbers.
There may be redundancies however. I needed 182 lines of Java code to reach a result (print included). I need to refactor a bit but I don't think i can do much better.

Congratulations for your challenge, I hope it will be validated.

Here is my output below :
/*
Combi : 12 12 9 13
Intermediaires  1.33 10.67
Resultat correct : 23.67

Combi : 12 13 9 12
Intermediaires  25.0 0.75
Resultat correct : 24.25

Combi : 13 9 12 12
Intermediaires  0.75 12.25
Resultat correct : 24.25
*/

Hello Smelty,
In the test case number 9 composed by 10, 11, 13, 13.
The expected output is false.

However, I found three correct result combinations  after rounding the final resut. Here is my output :

/*
Combi : 11 13 13 10
Intermediaires  0.846 13.846
Resultat correct : 23.846

Combi : 13 13 10 11
Intermediaires  26.0 260.0
Resultat correct : 23.63

Combi : 13 11 10 13
Intermediaires  1.181 11.18
Resultat correct : 24.18
*/

I have two other test cases wrong but I didn't take into account parenthesis properly yet to reach an acceptable solution. I have to fix it from my side.

I think there is a mistake with this example :
"""
You can make 24 from 3, 3, 8, and 8
With 8/(3-(8/3))
8 / (3 - (8/3)) = 8 / (3 - 2) = 8
"""

I guess the answer would be :
8 * (3 - (3/8)) = 8 * (3 - 0) = 8 * 3 = 24

This example is quoted twice.
All other examples are correct.
It is a nice and fun exercice to pratice !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear enough to be solved, seems well rounded.

Good suggestion but the original version of 24 Game contains only numbers ranging from 1 -13, 0 is excluded.
Not sure if you want to follow the original rule or if you still want to include the 0 in this case?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice simple puzzle

I think I have already seen this puzzle here. Also binary output isn't recommended.
Here is my solution that displays the arithmetic expression to reach the solution with minimal parenthesis, with the numbers sorted as close as possible to their natural order. Perhaps this is the type of solution you were originally going for.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JnQMe3psVkyoaX1D6oCQ7It7jhXMTa8f/view?usp=sharing

Here is my solution. 
https://tech.io/snippet/SHksCyc
Nice Puzzle

Thanks, I was avoiding binary output due to the many possibilities for solutions. Also, can you show me the original puzzle? I made this puzzle after checking the database to see if there were duplicate puzzles.
Whether or not there is a 0 doesn't make too large of a difference, but including 0 forces solvers to include a check for division by 0 error :)
As mentioned in my reply above, you need the answer to be exactly 24, not rounded to 24. Thanks for the feedback though!

Thanks for the feedback!
How is 9,12,12,13 possible? It appears that in all of your outputs are not 24, but 24.25 or 23.67. The puzzle requires it to be exactly 24, not a decimal that is rounded to 24 :)

The reason this is an easy puzzle is that the general feedback leans towards easy rather than medium.
Thanks again for the feedback :)

I think that if you ask for actual expression and not binary output this makes the puzzle a more challenging (medium level I think) and more suitable for codingame rules.
If you ask for the minimal sorting of the numbers (such that if you sort all permutations then your solution would use the lowest) and write as little parenthesis as needed in the solution, this makes the solution unique.
For example, here are some of my outputs:
(4+12-13)*8
8*9/(12-9)
8/(3-8/3)
4/(1-5/6)
I think it's more fun this way.
I have looked in the search and couldn't find it but pretty sure I've seen it. Many other puzzles also don't come up when I write their name in the search. It doesn't seem to work very well.
alright, I will try working on it!
